Chapter 6: The Bodhisattva of No Speech
At that time, the World-Honored One was still in the great jeweled abode between the realms of desire and form, surrounded by the great assembly, expounding the Dharma.
At that time, a son was born in the house of General Shizi in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha.
When he was born, many gods in the sky said like this:
Young boy!

You should remember the Dharma and contemplate the Dharma. Whatever you say, do not speak of worldly matters. You should always proclaim the supramundane Dharma. You should always guard your speech, be careful with your words, and speak little. Do not give rise to thoughts and speculations about worldly matters. Rely on the meaning, do not rely on the words.

At that time, after the young boy heard these words, he no longer cried or acted like an infant. For seven days, his complexion was harmonious and pleasant, and he was delighted to see people, never blinking his eyes.
At that time, someone said to his parents:
This child is inauspicious and should not be raised.
Why is that?
Because he is mute and cannot speak.
His parents replied:

Although this child cannot speak, his faculties are complete and without deficiency. We should know that this child will surely have blessings and virtues, and is not a person of inauspicious and meager blessings.
They gave him the name Wordless.

At that time, the young Wordless gradually grew up to be like an eight-year-old child. Wherever he went, people enjoyed seeing him. He happily went to listen and receive the Dharma wherever the Dharma wheel was turned, but his mouth did not proclaim anything.
At that time, the young Wordless, by the Buddha's spiritual power, went to the Jeta Grove with his parents, relatives, and kinsmen.

Having arrived, he saw the Buddha and gave rise to joy in his heart. He bowed in reverence, made offerings, circumambulated to the right three times, put his palms together, and stood there. He also saw the bodhisattvas who had come from the ten directions and gave rise to a greatly joyful mind.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The sons born to General Siá¹ƒha have complete faculties but cannot speak. What evil karma has caused this?
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
You should not speak lightly of this youth like this.
Why is it so?
This person is a great bodhisattva who has planted various roots of goodness in the presence of immeasurable and boundless buddhas and is irreversible on the path to bodhi.
When this child was born, many devas came to admonish him, saying:
'Excellent!
Youth!

You should remember the true Dharma and contemplate the true Dharma. Do not proclaim worldly matters, but always expound the meaning of transcending the world. Always guard your speech, be careful with your words, and speak little. Do not give rise to thoughts and speculations about worldly matters, but rely on the meaning and not on the words.
ÅšÄriputra!
In this way, the youth was instructed by the gods, and therefore remained silent in thought and attained the four dhyÄnas.
ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Intent manifested such a body, and was able to tame innumerable beings. Therefore, he remained silent and did not speak.
ÅšÄriputra!
I now expound this MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta SÅ«tra, and Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Intent will be able to greatly benefit innumerable beings in this.

At that time, Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Light, by the power of his own vows and spiritual penetrations, caused the devas, dragons, yakshas, gandharvas, asuras, garudas, kinnaras, mahoragas, bhikshus, bhikshunis, upasakas, and upasikas to each see a great lotus flower in their right hands, like a chariot wheel, with color and fragrance complete, supremely subtle and delightful to behold, with a bodhisattva sitting cross-legged on each flower platform, his body adorned with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks.
Then, after displaying such great spiritual powers, Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Light bowed his head and joined his palms, saying:ğŸ”½Homage to the Buddha!
Homage to the Buddha!
All the bodhisattvas in the lotus flower platforms also said the same thing:ğŸ”½Homage to the Buddha!
Homage to the Buddha!

Having spoken these words, the earth of worlds as numerous as the sands of ten Ganges Rivers shook in six ways, and the devas in the sky made offerings to the Buddha with wonderful incense, flowers, and various kinds of music.

At that time, the speechless one, by the Buddha's spiritual power and his own vow power, rose into the sky with the bodhisattvas to the height of seven tÄla trees, and facing the Buddha, spoke a verse, saying:
The TathÄgata, without form, manifests form, and also is not attached to form.
If there are sentient beings who enter the Buddha's Dharma, how should they know the true form?
The TathÄgata is not in the aggregate of form, nor is the TathÄgata apart from form;
The TathÄgata has already transcended all aggregates of form, but out of compassion for sentient beings, he manifests form.
Out of compassion for sentient beings, the TathÄgata adorns his form with the major and minor marks,
Yet he preaches to the assembly that there is truly no form or marks, and therefore the TathÄgata is difficult to fathom.
The TathÄgata's true Dharma is without written words; apart from written words, there is no sound.
Without written words, there is nothing to say; profoundly tranquil, there is no awareness.
Just as the Buddha previously sat under the bodhi tree, the dharmas he awakened to are also like this.
These dharmas are without written words or sounds, also without fabrication, and nothing to say.
Such dharmas are without characteristics, also far removed from all characteristics.
If all dharmas are without characteristics, how does the TathÄgata expound them?
The TathÄgata is fully endowed with great kindness and compassion, and therefore he has pity and benefits [beings].
He expounds the inexpressible Dharma, and also knows that the true is inexpressible.
The TathÄgata knows the inexpressible, and also knows that the nature of sounds is empty and tranquil.
He truly understands all meanings, and therefore he is called the Buddha, the Truly Awakened One.
The Dharma that is spoken is called conventional truth, which the TathÄgata truly realizes,
Conventional truth does not go beyond the nature of non-existence, it cannot be fabricated and has no fixed point.
The ultimate truth has no form or appearance, but for the sake of the multitude, various forms are shown,
The unsurpassed Honored One knows the Dharma and non-Dharma, and expounds it for the sake of sentient beings.
When I was first born, I received the words of the gods, therefore I am silent and have nothing to say,
With utmost sincerity, I contemplate the Dharma and ponder the Dharma, therefore I do not see form and sound.
If one can enter the profound Dharma realm, then there will be no form, sound, and so forth,
If one can distance oneself from the karma of the mind, then one can distance oneself from the karma of speech.
No speech is precisely speech, although there is speech, there is also no speech,
Speech is neither created nor spoken, because the inherent nature of language is quiescent.
I now single-mindedly contemplate enlightenment and also single-mindedly cultivate the path.
I now speak this unsurpassed truth and will certainly attain the true path.
My mind does not attain the path of enlightenment, nor does speech or verbal action attain it.
Unsurpassed enlightenment is emptiness, its nature originally always tranquil.
Just as the nature of enlightenment, so is sound, not seeing or grasping the nature of dharmas.
My sound is thus invisible, and the sought-after enlightenment is also like this.
For the sake of enlightenment, there is cultivation, but this practice also does not reach anywhere.
This practice is thus without reaching anywhere, therefore the place of enlightenment is not a place.
The six perfections are like enlightenment, and all wholesome dharmas are also like this.
All languages are without language, in the absence of language, one is able to speak.
If there is generosity with wonderful sounds, the master of generosity and the wealth,
Such generosity is enlightenment, all of which is inexpressible.
If generosity can be spoken of, the essence of enlightenment should also be expressible,
The nature of enlightenment is like space, and all sounds are also like this.
If there is a mind that can truly know, and having known, can also proclaim the sounds,
Following the knowledge of these sounds and abiding in cessation, this is the true characteristic of enlightenment.
If one can distance oneself from the actions of body, speech, and mind, and all afflictions are also thus,
This is all the perfections, the true nature of dharmas spoken by the TathÄgata.
Generosity is not in enlightenment, and enlightenment is not in generosity,
Such two dharmas are sounds, also without abiding and without reaching anywhere.
One is a true great bodhisattva.ğŸ”½If one does not give rise to arrogance when practicing generosity,
One is the unsurpassed great benefactor.ğŸ”½Upholding the precepts is sound,
It has no form or color, and does not reach anywhere.ğŸ”½All dharmas are unborn and unceasing,
This is the unsurpassed characteristic of upholding the precepts.ğŸ”½Such precepts cannot be created,
And also have no bodily, verbal, or mental actions.ğŸ”½If they do not arise or cease, and are not created,
How can they be called precepts?ğŸ”½In order to disseminate them, sounds are emitted,
And beings establish names, calling them precepts.ğŸ”½Just as the precepts are, so is sound,
In this way, the two dharmas are both without outflows.ğŸ”½Because the mouth speaks for the sake of the precepts,
Various adornments are set up.ğŸ”½Sound is actually without adornments,
Truly knowing that it does not exist.
One can turn this precept towards enlightenment.ğŸ”½The sound of precepts and enlightenment,
These two dharmas are like empty space.ğŸ”½If one can know in this way,
This person then practices the place of precepts,ğŸ”½And can reach the other shore of precepts,
That place is very profound and difficult to see.ğŸ”½Speaking of the sound of patience is precisely emptiness,
The nature of emptiness has no place and no creation,ğŸ”½Patience and emptiness are two dharmas,
Without distinction, like empty space.ğŸ”½The sound of patience is not made of form,
It cannot be seen or touched,ğŸ”½If there is the cultivation of an impartial mind,
This is the true characteristic of patience.ğŸ”½Although patience is moment by moment extinguished,
It always accompanies the physical body,ğŸ”½All written words are without outflows,
Sentient beings establish the name of patience.
That is the unsurpassed patience,ğŸ”½If one can endure and be patient,
That is also the unsurpassed patience.ğŸ”½If sentient beings were to crush one's body,
Crushing it to bits like sesame seeds,ğŸ”½Contemplating the body as if it were dry grass and wood,
That is called physical patience.ğŸ”½If one hears harsh scolding and abuse,
One's mind remains unmoved, abiding in the Dharma,ğŸ”½Contemplating sounds as if they were empty space,
That is the unsurpassed verbal patience.ğŸ”½If one can penetrate the causes of afflictions,
And be free from all afflictions,ğŸ”½That is called mental patience,
Not defiled by any afflictions.ğŸ”½Just as patience is the nature of enlightenment,
So are the actions of body, speech, and mind.ğŸ”½If one can turn this towards enlightenment,
That is called attaining enlightenment.
If there are sentient beings who diligently practice, superior, middling, and inferior, coarse and subtle,
Cultivating and accumulating for immeasurable eons, they will attain nothing and have no ultimate.
If one does not attain diligence, therefore enlightenment is called non-attainment,
If one can attain nothing in all dharmas, that is the unsurpassed diligent practice.
If there is such diligent practice, it is neither increased nor decreased, like space,
Such is the great bodhisattva, diligently practicing with fearlessness.
All meditations have no accumulation, no creation, and no destination,
If one contemplates all dharmas, that is the true perfection of meditation.
Far from all evil forms, evil body and evil speech are also so,
Able to burn all afflictions, that is the true perfection of meditation.
If one can contemplate the true nature of the mind, one will also not see anything in all dharmas.
If one can be without mind and far remove the mind, this is the true perfection of meditation.
If one can contemplate the mind and bodhi, this is the unsurpassed true view.
If there is such a true view, it will not be difficult to attain bodhi.
If one can know and see the absence of written words, all dharmas are without arising and ceasing.
If one makes such a contemplation and view, this is called great wisdom.
Although one may speak with the mouth about wisdom, wisdom also does not abide in the voice of the mouth.
If one knows that the voice of the mouth is actually without sound, this is the true nature of wisdom.
If a dharma has no abiding here or there, there is also no place to abide in the middle.
The nature of all dharmas has no place to abide, this is the unsurpassed great wisdom.
No characteristics, no nature,
No two aspects of accepting and rejecting - this is called the unsurpassed great wisdom.ğŸ”½If one contemplates all the perfections,
Their nature is equal, like empty space,
This is called the absence of equality, able to contemplate the equality of all dharmas.ğŸ”½If one can be equal in all dharmas,
One can also contemplate the equality of sentient beings,
And equally contemplate all Buddhas, the wisdom attained is without equality.ğŸ”½If the wise bodhisattvas
Can contemplate such unequaled dharmas,
They will attain the unsurpassed fruit of enlightenment, just as it was attained by the Buddhas of the past.

When Bodhisattva Inexpressible spoke this verse, the assembly of twelve thousand koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of sentient beings gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, and sixty thousand bodhisattvas attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

At that time, the bodhisattvas in the flower-adorned platform all rose from their seats, bowed their heads to the Buddha, respectfully made offerings of wonderful lotus flowers to the bodhisattva Inexhaustible, and proclaimed with their mouths,
We are the ones who know gratitude, and we now repay our gratitude.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra said:
World-Honored One!
Why did the bodhisattvas make such a statement, saying:
'We are the ones who know gratitude, and we now repay our gratitude'?
The Buddha said:
ÅšÄriputra!
These bodhisattvas all aroused the mind of enlightenment because of the bodhisattva Inexhaustible. Therefore, they say:
'We are the ones who know gratitude, and we now repay our gratitude.'
Now, they again listen to and accept this MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta SÅ«tra because of the bodhisattva Inexhaustible, and come to see and make offerings to me.
At that time, the bodhisattva Inexhaustible addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
I have some doubts that I now wish to ask about. I only pray that the TathÄgata will mercifully grant permission.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Ask as you wish and I will explain for you.
At that time ÅšÄriputra said to Inexhaustible:
Virtuous one!
If there are no words, how can you ask?
Venerable One!
All dharmas are all without words, without letters, and without speech.
Why is it so?
Because the nature of all sentient beings is without words, and because of contemplation, sounds come out.
If there is no contemplation, how can there be sounds?
How can they be spoken?
How can there be letters?
Venerable One!
In contemplation there are no letters and no sounds. Apart from contemplation, there are also no sounds or letters. The essence of contemplation is not contemplation.
I create words without conceptualization, and because of conceptualization I have great merit. If one can contemplate such profound dharmas, this is called the twelve links of dependent arising.
If it arises from conditions, it is then empty and quiescent, without fixed characteristics. If there is such true knowledge, it is the true knowledge of the nature of dharmas.
Great Virtuous One!

All dharmas arise from the combination of causes and conditions, and within the combination there is truly no creator, no birth, no emergence. Therefore, all dharmas are without master, without sound, without voice, without mind, without conceptualization, and not without conceptualization.
Why is it so?
Because of inverted causes and conditions, there is emergence and cessation.
Therefore, if there are those who ask, listen, and explain, they are neither combined nor scattered, with one characteristic and no characteristics.
Great Virtuous One!
Those who ask difficult questions have great compassion. I have great compassion, and therefore I ask the Buddha.
Such a question is a question of compassion, not a verbal question.
Verbal questions are the questions of the Å›rÄvakas. The Å›rÄvakas are attached to sounds, so they are called Å›rÄvakas. Bodhisattvas are universally compassionate, so they have no verbal questions.
ÅšÄriputra said:
Good man!
If the nature of all dharmas is indeterminate, then the nature of all sentient beings is also indeterminate. If they are indeterminate, for whom do bodhisattvas cultivate compassion?
Venerable One!

If all sentient beings had a determinate nature, then all bodhisattvas would never cultivate compassion. All sentient beings are actually not sentient beings. It is due to delusion that they give rise to the notion of sentient beings. Therefore, bodhisattvas cultivate the mind of compassion in order to destroy delusion and proclaim the absence of self.
Venerable One!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not proclaim the true Dharma in order to destroy existence. They do not cultivate loving-kindness and compassion and proclaim the true Dharma in order to destroy self, life, or person. It is in order to know the profound dharma realm as it truly is that they proclaim the Dharma.
The true Dharma realm is the samÄdhi of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.
ÅšÄriputra said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
I also truly understand this, so I asked you to test your wisdom. I asked in order to increase the Buddha's teachings and to benefit sentient beings.
At that time, Bodhisattva Inexhaustible Speech addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As it is said in the sÅ«tras, there are two causes and conditions that can give rise to right views, namely hearing sounds and proper contemplation.
I only pray that out of compassion you will extensively explain this for the bodhisattvas, on how hearing sounds and proper contemplation give rise to right views.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Listen attentively with utmost sincerity, and I shall explain this for you in detail.
Good man!

Listening to the Dharma for the sake of the mind of enlightenment is hearing the sound, recollecting the mind of enlightenment with utmost sincerity is proper reflection, and contemplating the mind of enlightenment is right view.
Furthermore, good man!
Listening to the Dharma for the sake of the path to enlightenment is called hearing the sound.
Not being apart from the path is proper reflection, and abiding in accordance with the Dharma is right view.
Listening to the Dharma for the sake of taming the mind is called hearing the sound.

Being apart from evil thoughts is proper reflection, and attaining wholesome thoughts is right view.ğŸ”½Listening to the Dharma for the sake of adorning wholesome dharmas is called hearing the sound, cultivating adornments is proper reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is right view.
Listening to the wholesome Dharma is called hearing the sound, increasing wholesome dharmas is proper reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is right view.
Listening to the teaching of generosity is called hearing the sound, being able to give up everything is proper reflection, and not seeking rewards is right view.

Listening to the aggregate of morality is called hearing the sound, protecting morality with a sincere mind is called good reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.ğŸ”½Listening to the forbearance of the Dharma is called hearing the sound, not retaliating when beaten or scolded is good reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.
Listening to vigor is called hearing the sound, destroying laziness is good reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.
Listening to samÄdhi is called hearing the sound, being able to purify body and mind is good reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.
Listening to the aggregate of wisdom is called hearing the sound, and after hearing it, correctly contemplating it is good reflection, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.

Listening to the four methods of gathering disciples is called hearing the sound, gathering sentient beings is good reflection, and knowing that these methods of gathering have no grasping, no creation, are empty, and do not exist is called right view.

Listening to the Dharma of the five supernormal knowledges is called hearing the sound, attaining lightness of body and mind is called good contemplation, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.
Listening to the four unobstructed [abilities] is called hearing the sound, cultivating the unobstructed is called good contemplation, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.

Listening to the Dharma of the four foundations is called hearing the sound, diligently cultivating the four foundations is called good contemplation, and aspiring towards enlightenment is called right view.
Listening to the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment is called hearing the sound;

If one hears the teaching of the four establishments of mindfulness, it is the establishment of mindfulness, the teaching of abandonment is the establishment of the four right efforts, the teaching of the aggregate of concentration is the establishment of the four bases of supernatural power, the teaching of fearlessness is the establishment of the faculties, the teaching of indestructibility is the establishment of the powers, the teaching of separation from afflictions is the establishment of the seven factors of enlightenment, and the teaching of true knowledge of the Dharma is the establishment of the eightfold path, this is good contemplation;
Not attached to annihilation or permanence, aspiring towards enlightenment with such a path is called right view.

Listening to the Dharma of the Four Noble Truths is called hearing the sound. Knowing suffering, abandoning the cause, realizing cessation, and cultivating the path is good reflection. Seeing such a Dharma as unborn and unceasing is called right view.
Listening to the three liberations is called hearing the sound;
Faith in the emptiness samÄdhi, not fearing the signless, and not doubting the wishless is good reflection;
Aspiring to bodhi with such a Dharma is called right view;
Cultivating the emptiness samÄdhi to clearly see the mind, cultivating the signless to eliminate thoughts, and cultivating the wishless to seek existence is called right view.
Listening to the Dharma of generating the mind is called hearing the sound. Cultivating the bodhisattva path is good reflection. The mind not retreating is called right view.
Obtaining a good spiritual friend is called hearing the sound. Making offerings and being close is called good reflection. Accepting his teachings is called right view.
Listening to the Dharma realm is called hearing the sound. Contemplating the Dharma realm is good reflection. Abiding in accordance with the Dharma is called right view.
Seeing the Buddha, the World-Honored One, is called hearing the sound. Remembering the bodhisattvas is called good contemplation. Attaining the ultimate path is called right view.

Initially listening to the eighty-four thousand aggregates of the Dharma is called hearing the sound. Observing sentient beings' practices in this way is called contemplation. Taming the eighty-four thousand faculties is called right view.
Good man!
Following any causes and conditions that can give rise to good dharmas is called hearing the sound.
Having heard, not separating from the causes and conditions of good dharmas is called good contemplation.
Wishing to attain bodhi through such dharmas is called right view.
Good man!
These two dharmas are without distinction, namely good contemplation and right view.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are equal and non-dual. This good contemplation is able to contemplate equality, which is right view.ğŸ”½That which is without increase or decrease is right view.
That which is without grasping or abandoning is right view.
No action and no doer is right view.ğŸ”½No thought and no contemplation is right view.
No mindfulness and no foundation of mindfulness is right view.
No action and no thought is right view.
No one and no two is right view.
One gate, one flavor, one vehicle, one practice, its nature is one.

Without various afflictions, arrogance, and other bonds, without hearing, without speaking, without defilement, without purity, the nature of the Dharma realm cannot be discriminated, like thusness, unmoving, equal in the three times.

Without self and what belongs to self, without sentient beings, life, or person, without words, without sound, cannot be proclaimed, unknown, unseen, in all dharmas, the mind of contentment, far removed from various characteristics, cutting off all joyful thoughts and contemplations, dwellings, up to praising the Buddha without giving rise to the concept of Buddha.
When entering concentration, contemplating such profound Dharma realms is called good contemplation.
Having arisen from concentration, he expounds such a profound Dharma realm for sentient beings, which is called right view.
When this Dharma was being spoken, ten thousand bodhisattvas attained this right view.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra said to the bodhisattva Inexhaustible:
Good man!
From whom did you hear the Dharma and attain right view?
The bodhisattva Inexhaustible said:
Venerable one!
If there is one who does not attain the mind of enlightenment in the past, present, or future, I have heard from him and attained right view.

Contemplating the equality of the three times and the equality of all dharmas, one does not give rise to discursive thoughts about all dharmas, and one's mind does not abide in conditioned or unconditioned [phenomena].
Far removed from all characteristics of sentient beings, one cultivates austerities for the sake of sentient beings, and also far removed from two kinds of characteristics;
first, the characteristic of sentient beings;
second, the characteristic of the mind.

Far removed from the two extremes, knowing the true nature of dharmas, the true nature of dharmas is non-existent, penetrating all the profound dharmas of the buddhas, not giving rise to arrogance and saying 'I know.'
Venerable One!
I listen to and accept the true Dharma from this person, and this person also does not proclaim a single word, yet causes all to joyfully listen to it.
Knowing the true Dharma is inexpressible, yet proclaiming it for the sake of sentient beings;
Emerging in the world, yet not defiled by the world, ultimately cultivating without being able to know cultivation and non-cultivation. I listen to and accept the true Dharma from this person.

Abiding in the nature of dharmas, not giving rise to discrimination in the nature of sentient beings, contemplating the nature of sentient beings and the empty nature of dharmas as all being equal, I hear the Dharma from such a person.
This person does not sit under the bodhi tree, does not arise, does not walk, does not sleep, does not lie down, does not doze off, does not wake up, yet attains bodhi.

Having attained enlightenment, they never make the appearance of attaining enlightenment. All sentient beings also do not know that they have attained enlightenment, because non-attainment is the attainment, and there is no appearance of attainment.
Venerable One!

The true Dharma is without light. That which is without light has no location. That which has no location is without a body. That which is without a body is without fear. That which is without fear is

not emerging. That which is not emerging is non-arising. That which is non-arising is non-ceasing. That which is non-ceasing is non-attachment. That which is non-attachment is non-moving. That which is non-moving is
non-changing. That which is non-changing is without haste and without darkness. That which is without haste and without darkness is without discursive thought.
That which is without discursive thought is without the world. That which is without the world is without a vessel. That which is without a vessel is
without greed. That which is without greed is naturally pure. That which is naturally pure does not combine with afflictions.
Affliction means not in accord with afflictions, which is non-inverted. Non-inverted is precisely equality.

Equality is precisely reality. Reality is neither arising nor ceasing. Neither arising nor ceasing is called arising from causes and conditions. Arising from causes and conditions is precisely not going or coming. Not going or coming is precisely without objects. Without objects is precisely without phrases. Without phrases is precisely not insanity. Not insanity is precisely no hearing. No hearing is precisely no action. No action is precisely no abiding. No abiding is precisely no letters. No letters is precisely no characteristics. No characteristics is precisely transcending the phrases of mind, thought, and cognition. Transcending mind, thought, and cognition is precisely quiescence. Quiescence is precisely no heat. No heat is precisely no anger. No anger is precisely ultimate. Ultimate is precisely non-existence. Non-existence is precisely nirvana. This is called the Dharma.
Venerable One!
This is the true Dharma, this is expounding the Dharma, this is listening to the Dharma, this is right view.
Venerable One!

The one with right view does not see the body, does not see bodily actions, does not see views, does not give rise to attachment, does not perceive or contemplate - this is called the noble one's right view, right seeing of the Buddha's Dharma.
Furthermore, Venerable One!
Contemplating ignorance and craving as being no different from liberation is called right view.
Having seen in this way, not clinging or grasping, this is called the noble one's view.
Furthermore, Venerable One!

Contemplating greed, anger, and delusion as being equal to emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, not seeing characteristics, seeing the characteristic of signlessness, this is called the noble one's view.
Not contemplating one or two, being equal to all dharmas, is called the noble one's right view.
Furthermore, Venerable One!

If one can contemplate the equality of oneself and sentient beings, due to the equality of sentient beings, the TathÄgata is equal; due to the equality of the TathÄgata, the Buddha Dharma is equal; due to the equality of the Buddha Dharma, the noble assembly is equal; due to the equality of the noble assembly, great compassion is equal; due to the equality of compassion, space is equal. Abiding in non-abiding in this way is called the noble right view.
Venerable One!
Just as all dharmas, so is sound;
Just as sound, that is the noble view, that is the right view.
Venerable One!
The noble right view also has no arising or emergence. If there is no arising or emergence, from whom does one listen to the Dharma?
ÅšÄriputra said:
According to my understanding of what you have said, all dharmas are beyond words.
Venerable One!
It is so, it is so!
All dharmas are indeed beyond words.
Good man!
If one says that the TathÄgata has accomplished merit, what kind of offense does one incur in such words?
Venerable One!
If one speaks in this way, one should know that this person has great faults.
Why is it so?
Because the TathÄgata's merits are indeterminate.
Why is it so?
Because having no merit and no offense is called the TathÄgata.
If one regards the TathÄgata as having merits, this is called desire.
One who has desire is one with great desire, and having desire and great desire is an offense.
Good man!
How can one be said to be without offense?
